title: What will be the closing spot price for Brent crude oil on 22 June 2018?
possible_answers: More than $75 but less than $80 per barrel
preds:
Oil Prices Rise on Declining U.S. Supplies, Attacks on Libyan Ports McFarlane and Molinski (2018) June 20, states that: Oil prices firmed on Wednesday, supported by declining U.S. oil inventories, a rebel attack in Libya and expectations that international oil producers meeting this week may decide to boost production, but moderately (Para. 1). The Energy Information Administration said Wednesday morning U.S. stockpiles of crude oil fell by 5.9 million barrels last week, compared with analysts’ expectations for a 2.5 million-barrel decline. That puts total U.S. commercial crude oil stockpiles at 427 million barrels, the lowest level since March (Para. 3). While the headline number on oil inventories from Wednesday’s weekly EIA report was bullish, the data also included some bearish figures. Stockpiles of gasoline and distillates rose by 3.3 million barrels and 2.7 million barrels, respectively, offsetting the 5.9-million-barrel drop in crude stockpiles (Para.10). Also, motor gasoline supplied to the market—which investors use as a proxy for demand—fell by 553,000 barrels a day last week, to 9.3 million barrels a day, suggesting summer driving demand may not be quite as robust as forecast (Para. 14). McFarlane, S. & Molinski, D. (2018). Oil Prices Rise on Declining U.S. Supplies, Attacks on Libyan Ports. The Wall Street Journal. Markets. Oil Markets. June 20, 2018. Retrieved from 
https://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-climbs-ahead-of-opec-meeting-1529490465 Spot Prices

June 13th price was $75.07 and futures have come off about $0.80 since then. This gives the edge to below $75, unless someone sees a reason for an upward bias in the next six trading days.

Maybe ~78 but could steady out to 75 by June 22nd. Cartel probably wants to squeeze more out of us and get it back over 80 as the new long term price. Send in master negotiator Trumpy, he'll sort it out!  Anyhow nice to see wider spreads with some in 85+ and <70. Just not seeing it now in short term, but who knows. June 13th could be blow up day in Singapore ;-p but hopefully it calms down again by June 22nd.

Portfolio managers cut their net long position in Brent by almost 50 million barrels in the week to May 22, the largest one-week reduction since before the rally started in June 2017. Recent sharp falls in oil prices, especially Brent, are therefore not surprising, given that fund managers have been steadily liquidating long positions and adding shorts for more than a month.

I performed an econometric analysis of publicly available data from several sources (EIA.gov, Quandl, etc.) to create a model and generate a simple forecast of oil prices. I will update my forecast at a later date.

I'm using a model here that I developed for the HFC on the MATRICS platform: Using spreadsheet with closing spot prices for Brent crude oil prices for each day going back to May 2008 (from http://www.macrotrends.net/2480/brent-crude-oil-prices-10-year-daily-chart), How often does the share price fluctuate (expressed in percentage up or down terms) across a span of 22 trading days (given 22 trading days remain) from yesterday's closing price (78.34) into each of the five answer "buckets"? Based on today's price, the buckets are: 
* Price falls by more than 10.7% 
* Price falls by 10.6% to 4.3% 
* Price falls by less than 4.3% or rises by less than 2.1% 
* Price increases by 2.1% to 8.5% 
* Price increases by more than 8.5% Given the very similar question about gold prices (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/736474), I just note how much more volatile oil prices are than gold.  The "buckets" for answers are much wider for this question (in percentage terms) but, even so, extremes of price movements are far more common for oil than for gold. In fact, a question like "Will the oil price change by MORE than $5 per barrel (in either direction)?" is pretty much a 50:50 proposition.  In short, it is highly likely to change, but no-one can usefully forecast in which direction. Wow! *************************
[EDIT]
Oops - calculated using 22 trading days remaining; should have been _23_.
$78,71 May 20. Tight infrastructure in USA. Venezuela issues. Russia and Saudi reductions. Iran. Increased demand/decreased supplies.
Oil has been on an upward trend in last  5 weeks. Lots of tension in the Middle East. Therefore the most likely is between $70 and $85

7:01 PM BST 05/18/18
$78.76 USD -0.54 -0.68% The Wall Street Journal Website. (2018). Brent Crude April 2018. The Wall Street Journal. Retrieve from 
http://quotes.wsj.com/futures/UK/BRENT%20CRUDE
Looming Iranian sanctions seem to be driving the market.

Oil Prices Keep Climbing Despite Stronger Dollar Sider and Salvaterra (2018) May 15, states that: Oil prices rose in volatile trading Tuesday, shrugging off a strong dollar and weak equity markets. U.S. crude futures rose 35 cents, or 0.5%, to $71.31 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Brent, the global benchmark, rose 20 cents, or 0.3%, to $78.43 a barrel on ICE Futures Europe, the highest since November 2014. Oil prices have run up rapidly amid turmoil in the Middle East and the prospect of trade sanctions against Iran. Both benchmarks are up around 4% this month. They both pulled back from highs reached in earlier trading Tuesday as the dollar surged and equity markets fell, but still ended the day higher. Oil and the dollar often move in opposite directions, since a stronger dollar makes oil more expensive for buyers using foreign currencies, reducing demand (Para. 1-3). Sider, A. & Salvaterra, N. (2018). Oil Prices Keep Climbing Despite Stronger Dollar. The Wall Street Journal. Markets. Oil Markets. May 15, 2018. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-rises-to-new-three-year-highs-1526381561 OPEC Output Rises on Higher Crude Production in Saudi Arabia Alessi (2018) May 14, states that: OPEC said Monday its crude oil output ticked up slightly last month, while total global supply continued to grow largely due to robust U.S. shale production (Para. 1). More recently, prices have been bolstered by President Donald Trump’s decision to pull the U.S. out of a 2015 international agreement to curb Iran’s nuclear program. The move is set to reimpose U.S. economic sanctions on Iran, hindering the oil output of the Islamic Republic—a major OPEC member—and reducing global supply. However, Saudi Arabia has already indicated it could ramp up its own production to make up for any supply loss from Iran (Para. 6). Alessi, C. (2018). OPEC Output Rises on Higher Crude Production in Saudi Arabia. The Wall Street Journal. Markets. Oil Markets. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/opec-output-rises-on-higher-crude-production-in-saudi-arabia-1526295316

Saudis want to $80 and their effort to reach that level is advancing but may take longer than the month or so until June 22.  Certainly one can see enough actual and potential  political conflicts to justify the rise.   World demand also is a positive factor in petro prices. Really the question is when will we see $80 not if we will see $80.
At fast pace, price of oil can rise $10 per barrel in a month. Given current price, and rising prices as entering summer, expect that by end of June will be on higher range.

As always with market prices, I am starting from the view that prices are volatile and probability distributions ought to be wide. The price is currently being supported by geopolitical tensions. I do not see those as abating significantly in the short term. But there is also a question of how impactful the Iranian sections will be. It remains to be seen what OPEC does in reaction to the Iran situation. Will they increase production? And could European buyers continue to purchase from Iran? Either one of those could stem the bullishness coming from US sanctions. A bearish factor is the rise in the number of US rigs [1], which will counteract future bullishness to some degree. The price is also near overbought levels with the RSI near 70.  [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-11/oil-set-for-a-second-weekly-gain-as-mideast-tensions-intensify
